questions.stem: A 5-year-old child watches as water is poured from a short, wide glass into a tall, narrow glass and insists the tall glass now contains more water. When asked to explain, the child says, "It's higher so there's more." Which TWO preoperational limitations BEST account for this error?

options.text: Centration and irreversibility
Animism and egocentrism
Transductive reasoning and centration
Egocentrism and irreversibility

questions.explanation: Conservation failure in the preoperational stage results from centration (focusing only on one dimension—the height of the water—while ignoring the width) and irreversibility (the inability to mentally reverse the pouring operation to recognize the quantity is unchanged). Egocentrism involves difficulty taking another's perspective, and animism involves attributing life to inanimate objects—neither directly explains conservation failure.

questions.stem: A clinician observes a 3-year-old who refers to the moon as "sleepy" and tells a stuffed animal not to be "scared" of the dark. According to Piaget, this behavior is MOST characteristic of:

options.text: Egocentrism
Animism
Transductive reasoning
Symbolic function

questions.explanation: Animism is the preoperational tendency to attribute lifelike qualities—feelings, intentions, and consciousness—to inanimate objects. Saying the moon is 'sleepy' and that a stuffed animal feels 'scared' exemplifies this. Egocentrism is the inability to take another's perspective. Symbolic function refers broadly to the ability to use mental representations. Transductive reasoning involves reasoning from one particular to another without logic.

questions.stem: Piaget used the three-mountain task to assess which cognitive limitation in preoperational children?

options.text: Conservation failure
Irreversibility
Egocentrism
Centration

questions.explanation: The three-mountain task specifically assesses egocentrism—the child's inability to take another person's visual perspective. Children in the preoperational stage select their own view of the three mountains rather than the view that would be seen by a doll seated on the opposite side. Conservation tasks assess centration and irreversibility.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old child says "I goed to the store" and "I have two foots." A developmental psychologist would interpret these errors as evidence of:

options.text: A language delay requiring speech-language evaluation
Overregularization, reflecting internalization of grammatical rules
Regression to an earlier stage of language development
Deficient phonological awareness skills

questions.explanation: Overregularization occurs when children apply learned grammatical rules (e.g., add -ed for past tense, add -s for plurals) to irregular forms. 'Goed' and 'foots' demonstrate that the child has internalized the rules but has not yet learned the exceptions. This is considered a sign of cognitive progress, not a language delay or regression.

questions.stem: A researcher observes that a 5-year-old talks aloud to herself while working on a challenging puzzle, saying things like "Okay, this piece goes here... no, turn it around... try the blue one." Vygotsky would characterize this self-directed speech as:

options.text: Egocentric speech reflecting the child's inability to take others' perspectives
Private speech serving a self-regulatory function that increases with task difficulty
Social speech intended to communicate with nearby adults
Inner speech that has not yet been fully internalized

questions.explanation: Vygotsky viewed private speech as a critical self-regulatory tool—not as egocentric (Piaget's interpretation). Private speech helps children plan and guide their behavior, increases during challenging tasks, and gradually becomes internalized as inner speech by around age 7. The child is not communicating with others but directing her own problem-solving.

questions.stem: Select ALL of the following that are characteristic limitations of Piaget's preoperational stage (ages 2–7).

options.text: Egocentrism—inability to take another person's perspective
Centration—focusing on one salient feature while ignoring others
Transitivity—inability to infer relationships between objects
Irreversibility—inability to mentally reverse a sequence of events
Horizontal décalage—staggered acquisition of conservation across domains

questions.explanation: Egocentrism, centration, and irreversibility are hallmark limitations of preoperational thought. Transitivity (if A > B and B > C, then A > C) is actually an achievement of the concrete operational stage, not a preoperational limitation. Horizontal décalage describes the staggered acquisition of conservation during the concrete operational stage, not a preoperational limitation.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that accurately describe Baumrind's authoritative parenting style.

options.text: High in both demandingness and responsiveness
Associated with high self-esteem, social competence, and self-regulation in children
Relies primarily on strict obedience without explanation
Sets clear expectations while encouraging autonomy and open communication
Produces uniformly positive outcomes regardless of cultural context

questions.explanation: Authoritative parenting is characterized by high demandingness combined with high responsiveness, clear standards paired with open communication and reasoned discipline, and is associated with positive child outcomes in Western cultures. However, cross-cultural research indicates that its effects may vary—authoritarian parenting may be adaptive in some collectivist cultures and high-risk neighborhoods. Relying on strict obedience without explanation describes authoritarian parenting.

questions.stem: Select ALL of the following that are TRUE regarding Theory of Mind (ToM) development in early childhood.

options.text: Most typically developing children pass false belief tasks between ages 4 and 5
Deficits in ToM are a hallmark feature of Autism Spectrum Disorder
The Sally-Anne task assesses the child's understanding that others can hold beliefs that differ from reality
ToM develops fully by age 3 in most children
ToM deficits are found exclusively in children with ASD and no other conditions

questions.explanation: ToM develops around ages 4–5, not age 3—prior to age 4, children typically fail false belief tasks. The Sally-Anne task tests understanding that others can hold false beliefs. ToM deficits are strongly associated with ASD ('mindblindness') but are not exclusive to ASD—they can appear in other conditions affecting social cognition. Therefore, both (d) and (e) are incorrect.

questions.stem: Select ALL of the following that accurately describe Kohlberg's cognitive-developmental stages of gender understanding.

options.text: Gender identity (ages 2–3): Children correctly label their own and others' gender
Gender stability (age 4): Children understand gender remains constant over time
Gender constancy (ages 6–7): Children understand gender is unchanged by superficial transformations
Gender schema formation precedes and is necessary for gender identity
Children begin actively seeking same-sex models immediately upon labeling their gender

questions.explanation: Kohlberg proposed three sequential stages: gender identity (~2–3), gender stability (~4), and gender constancy (~6–7). According to Kohlberg, children do not begin actively seeking gender-appropriate models until they achieve gender constancy—the final stage. Gender schema theory (Bem) is a separate framework that proposes schemas form once basic gender identity is established, but Kohlberg's theory holds that full constancy must be reached first.

questions.stem: Select ALL features that distinguish cooperative play from associative play in Parten's classification.

options.text: Children organize their play around a common goal
Children assign roles and negotiate rules
Children interact socially and share materials
Play requires Theory of Mind and executive function
Children play independently without direct interaction

questions.explanation: Cooperative play is distinguished from associative play by the presence of organized activity around a common goal, role assignment, and rule negotiation. Both cooperative AND associative play involve social interaction and material sharing—so (c) does not distinguish them. Playing independently without interaction describes parallel or solitary play. Cooperative play requires ToM (understanding others' intentions) and executive function (following rules, inhibiting impulses).

questions.stem: Match each Parten play stage with the behavior that BEST exemplifies it.

columns.text: Two children build with blocks at the same table but construct independent structures without interacting
A child stands at the edge of the sandbox watching others dig but does not participate
Children assign roles (doctor, patient) and act out a medical scenario together
Children in a sandbox share shovels and comment on each other's digging but have no shared plan

questions.explanation: Parallel play involves side-by-side activity with similar materials but no direct interaction. Associative play involves social interaction and sharing but no organized goal. Cooperative play involves organizing around a common goal with assigned roles. Onlooker play involves watching others play without participating. These distinctions are frequently tested on the EPPP.

questions.stem: Match each parenting style to its defining combination of demandingness and responsiveness.
questions.explanation: Baumrind's framework classifies parenting along two dimensions: demandingness (expectations for mature behavior and behavioral control) and responsiveness (warmth, acceptance, sensitivity). Authoritative = high/high; Authoritarian = high demand/low response; Permissive = low demand/high response; Uninvolved = low/low. Authoritative consistently predicts the best outcomes in Western samples.

questions.stem: For each preoperational limitation, select ALL Piagetian tasks or phenomena that are directly related to it. (Some tasks may relate to more than one limitation.)
questions.explanation: Egocentrism is demonstrated by the three-mountain task and is closely related to false belief task failure (both involve difficulty understanding that another person's perspective/knowledge differs from one's own). Centration and irreversibility both contribute to conservation failure in the liquid task—centration causes the child to focus only on height, and irreversibility prevents mental reversal of the pouring. Animism is demonstrated by attributing feelings to inanimate objects (e.g., the sun is 'happy').

questions.stem: For each gender development theory, select ALL mechanisms it emphasizes. (Theories may share mechanisms.)

columns.text: Organized knowledge networks filtering gender-relevant information
Identification with same-sex parent during phallic stage

questions.explanation: Kohlberg emphasizes a cognitive-developmental sequence (identity → stability → constancy). Gender Schema Theory (Bem) proposes that children develop organized schemas that filter gender-relevant information. Social Learning Theory (Bandura) emphasizes observation, imitation of same-sex models, and differential reinforcement. Psychoanalytic theory attributes gender development to identification with the same-sex parent during the phallic stage (Oedipus/Electra complex).

questions.stem: In the Sally-Anne false belief task, Sally places a marble in a {{blank1}} and leaves the room. While Sally is away, Anne moves the marble to a {{blank2}}. When asked where Sally will look for the marble, children who have developed Theory of Mind correctly say Sally will look in the {{blank3}}, while children who lack ToM incorrectly say she will look in the {{blank4}}.

options.text: basket
box
drawer
cupboard
basket
box
shelf
pocket
box (the marble's current location)
basket (where Sally left it)
both locations equally
neither location
basket (where Sally left it)
both locations equally
box (where the marble actually is)
a completely different location

questions.explanation: The Sally-Anne task (Baron-Cohen, Leslie, & Frith, 1985) is the classic test for false belief understanding. Sally places a marble in a basket, and Anne moves it to a box while Sally is absent. Children with ToM understand Sally's belief hasn't been updated—she will look in the basket. Children without ToM cannot separate their own knowledge from Sally's and say she will look in the box (the marble's actual location).

questions.stem: According to Vygotsky, private speech serves a {{blank1}} function and increases when tasks are {{blank2}}. Unlike Piaget, who viewed this self-directed talk as {{blank3}}, Vygotsky saw it as a bridge between social speech and {{blank4}}.

options.text: self-regulatory
communicative
expressive-emotional
socially reinforcing
extremely easy
moderately difficult
impossible to solve
socially oriented
self-regulatory and functional
internalized thought made audible
egocentric and nonfunctional
a sign of advanced cognition
inner (silent) thought
telegraphic speech
metalinguistic awareness
echolalia

questions.explanation: Vygotsky saw private speech as serving a self-regulatory function (planning, guiding behavior). Research confirms it increases when tasks are moderately difficult. Piaget viewed this talk as egocentric and nonfunctional, reflecting the child's inability to take another's perspective. Vygotsky proposed it as a developmental bridge: social speech → private speech → inner (silent) thought, internalized around age 7.

questions.stem: A 3-year-old child is shown a candy box that actually contains crayons. When asked what his friend (who hasn't looked inside) would think is in the box, the child says 'crayons.' Analyze this scenario.

options.text: The child cannot distinguish between his own knowledge and another's knowledge
Egocentrism limits the child's ability to represent another person's mental state
The child has a phonological processing deficit
The child's working memory capacity prevents dual representation
Theory of Mind has not yet fully developed
The child has Autism Spectrum Disorder
The child lacks symbolic function ability
The child is likely to pass false belief tasks within the next 1–2 years as ToM matures
If persistent beyond age 5, this difficulty may warrant assessment for social-cognitive deficits
The child requires immediate intervention for intellectual disability
The child's language development is severely delayed

questions.explanation: This is a classic false belief task. At age 3, most children fail because Theory of Mind has not yet fully developed. Contributing factors include the child's inability to distinguish own knowledge from another's (a hallmark of undeveloped ToM) and egocentrism. This is normative at age 3; most children pass by age 4–5. Persistent failure beyond age 5 could signal social-cognitive deficits associated with ASD, but failure at age 3 alone does not indicate ASD, intellectual disability, or language delay.

questions.stem: A parent sets firm limits on screen time, requires the child to complete chores, explains the reasoning behind all rules, warmly praises effort, and encourages the child to express opinions during family discussions. Analyze this parenting pattern.

options.text: High demandingness: clear rules, expectations, and behavioral standards
High responsiveness: warmth, reasoned discipline, and encouragement of autonomy
Low responsiveness: emphasis on obedience without emotional warmth
Low demandingness: minimal expectations for the child's behavior
Authoritative parenting style
Authoritarian parenting style
Permissive parenting style
Higher self-esteem, social competence, and academic achievement
Better self-regulation and emotional adjustment
Increased anxiety, lower self-esteem, and potential aggression
Poor impulse control, entitlement, and academic difficulties

questions.explanation: This parent demonstrates authoritative parenting—high in both demandingness (firm limits, chores, expectations) and responsiveness (explaining reasons, warmth, encouraging autonomy). Baumrind's research consistently associates authoritative parenting with the most positive developmental outcomes in Western cultures: high self-esteem, social competence, academic achievement, and good self-regulation. Anxiety/low self-esteem outcomes (p3) are associated with authoritarian parenting; impulsivity/entitlement (p4) with permissive parenting.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements about Piaget's preoperational stage that are CORRECT.
questions.passage: The preoperational stage spans approximately ages 2 to 7 and includes the symbolic function and intuitive thought substages. [The symbolic function substage (ages 2–4) is marked by the emergence of pretend play, drawing, and language use as mental representation tools]. [Conservation develops during the preoperational stage around age 5 as children master centration]. [Egocentrism, demonstrated by the three-mountain task, reflects the child's difficulty understanding that others may have different visual perspectives]. [Animism refers to the child's tendency to attribute lifelike qualities to inanimate objects, such as saying the sun is happy]. [The intuitive thought substage (ages 4–7) is characterized by logical operations and systematic hypothesis testing]. [Overregularization errors like 'goed' and 'foots' indicate that the child has internalized grammatical rules and is applying them to irregular forms].

highlightableSegments.text: The symbolic function substage (ages 2–4) is marked by the emergence of pretend play, drawing, and language use as mental representation tools
Conservation develops during the preoperational stage around age 5 as children master centration
Egocentrism, demonstrated by the three-mountain task, reflects the child's difficulty understanding that others may have different visual perspectives
Animism refers to the child's tendency to attribute lifelike qualities to inanimate objects, such as saying the sun is happy
The intuitive thought substage (ages 4–7) is characterized by logical operations and systematic hypothesis testing
Overregularization errors like 'goed' and 'foots' indicate that the child has internalized grammatical rules and is applying them to irregular forms

questions.explanation: Correct statements: (h1) The symbolic function substage does emerge ages 2–4 with pretend play, drawing, and language. (h3) Egocentrism is demonstrated by the three-mountain task. (h4) Animism is attributing lifelike qualities to inanimate objects. (h6) Overregularization reflects rule internalization. Incorrect: (h2) Conservation does NOT develop during the preoperational stage—it is a hallmark achievement of the concrete operational stage, and centration is a limitation, not something children 'master.' (h5) The intuitive thought substage involves primitive reasoning, NOT logical operations or hypothesis testing—those characterize concrete and formal operational stages.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements about gender development theories that are CORRECT.
questions.passage: Several theories explain gender development in early childhood. [According to Kohlberg, gender constancy (understanding gender is unchanged by superficial transformations) is achieved around ages 6–7 and is the final stage in his sequence]. [Gender schema theory proposes that children cannot form gender schemas until they achieve full gender constancy]. [Social learning theory emphasizes observation, imitation of same-sex models, and differential reinforcement as mechanisms of gender development]. [Kohlberg's sequence begins with gender stability, followed by gender identity, and ends with gender constancy]. [Bem's gender schema theory suggests that once basic gender identity is established, children actively filter new information through gender schemas]. [Research on Baumrind's parenting styles was initially conducted with diverse cross-cultural samples representing collectivist and individualist cultures equally].

highlightableSegments.text: According to Kohlberg, gender constancy (understanding gender is unchanged by superficial transformations) is achieved around ages 6–7 and is the final stage in his sequence
Gender schema theory proposes that children cannot form gender schemas until they achieve full gender constancy
Social learning theory emphasizes observation, imitation of same-sex models, and differential reinforcement as mechanisms of gender development
Kohlberg's sequence begins with gender stability, followed by gender identity, and ends with gender constancy
Bem's gender schema theory suggests that once basic gender identity is established, children actively filter new information through gender schemas
Research on Baumrind's parenting styles was initially conducted with diverse cross-cultural samples representing collectivist and individualist cultures equally

questions.explanation: Correct: (h1) Gender constancy is Kohlberg's final stage at ages 6–7. (h3) Social learning theory does emphasize observation, imitation, and reinforcement. (h5) Bem's theory holds that schemas form once basic gender identity (not constancy) is established. Incorrect: (h2) Gender schema theory proposes schemas form after basic gender identity, NOT after full constancy—this is a key distinction from Kohlberg. (h4) Kohlberg's sequence is identity → stability → constancy (not stability first). (h6) Baumrind's research was initially conducted primarily with White, middle-class American families, not diverse cross-cultural samples.

questions.stem: Arrange Parten's stages of play in correct developmental order from LEAST to MOST socially sophisticated.

items.text: Unoccupied play
Solitary play
Onlooker play
Parallel play
Associative play
Cooperative play

questions.explanation: Parten (1932) identified six stages of increasing social involvement: (1) Unoccupied play—no purposeful activity; (2) Solitary play—playing alone; (3) Onlooker play—watching others without participating; (4) Parallel play—playing alongside but not with others; (5) Associative play—interacting and sharing but no organized goal; (6) Cooperative play—organized play with common goals, roles, and rules. This progression reflects growing social cognition and self-regulation.

questions.stem: Arrange Kohlberg's stages of gender understanding in the correct developmental sequence from EARLIEST to LATEST.

items.text: Gender identity: Child correctly labels own gender and others' gender (~age 2–3)
Gender stability: Child understands gender remains the same over time (~age 4)
Gender constancy: Child understands gender is unchanged by superficial transformations (~age 6–7)
Child begins actively seeking same-sex models for imitation (post-constancy)
Strong gender-typed preferences consolidate in play, clothing, and peer interactions
Gender schemas become increasingly flexible in later childhood and adolescence

questions.explanation: Kohlberg proposed that gender understanding develops sequentially: (1) Gender identity (~2–3)—basic labeling; (2) Gender stability (~4)—understanding permanence over time; (3) Gender constancy (~6–7)—understanding permanence despite superficial changes. Only after constancy do children actively seek same-sex models, leading to consolidation of gender-typed preferences. Research shows that gender schemas gradually become more flexible in later childhood and adolescence as cognitive development allows more nuanced thinking.

questions.stem: A developmental researcher tracks two variables across early childhood in a sample of typically developing children: the percentage who pass false belief tasks and the frequency of private speech use during challenging tasks.
questions.question: Which statement BEST describes the relationship between these two developmental trends?

options.text: Both variables increase linearly throughout early childhood, suggesting a shared cognitive mechanism
False belief passing increases steadily while private speech peaks around ages 4–5 then declines as it becomes internalized—reflecting distinct but overlapping developmental trajectories
Private speech causes improvements in false belief understanding, as shown by their parallel increase
Both variables plateau after age 5, indicating that cognitive development stabilizes

questions.explanation: False belief task performance increases steadily from near-zero at age 2 to near-ceiling by age 7, reflecting the gradual maturation of Theory of Mind. Private speech follows an inverted-U pattern: it increases as children use it for self-regulation during the preschool years, peaks around ages 4–5, then declines as it becomes internalized as inner (silent) thought by age 7 (Vygotsky's theory). These are distinct developmental processes with different trajectories—correlation does not imply causation.

questions.stem: A longitudinal study follows children from ages 2 to 6, measuring vocabulary size (number of words) and the frequency of overregularization errors per 100 utterances.
questions.question: What does the trend in overregularization errors suggest about language development?

options.text: Overregularization errors indicate language regression and should be clinically evaluated
The increase and subsequent decrease in overregularization reflects a U-shaped learning curve: children first learn irregular forms, then overapply rules, then learn exceptions
Overregularization errors correlate perfectly with vocabulary size, suggesting they are caused by vocabulary growth alone
The decline in errors after age 4 indicates that children abandon grammatical rules in favor of rote memorization

questions.explanation: Overregularization follows a characteristic U-shaped pattern: children initially produce correct irregular forms through rote learning (e.g., 'went'), then begin overregularizing as they internalize grammatical rules (e.g., 'goed'), and finally learn exceptions to the rules. The peak around age 4 reflects active rule application—a sign of cognitive progress, not regression. The decline occurs as children learn irregular exceptions while retaining the rules. Vocabulary growth is concurrent but does not directly cause overregularization patterns.

questions.stem: Categorize each child behavior as MOST characteristic of the Piagetian substage or play stage it represents.

items.text: Using a banana as a pretend telephone during play
Insisting a tall narrow glass has more water than a short wide one
Assigning roles (mommy, daddy, baby) and acting out a family dinner scene together
Drawing a picture to represent their family even when family members are absent
Asking endless 'why' questions but using primitive, non-logical reasoning
Negotiating rules for a game of 'hospital' with assigned doctors, nurses, and patients

questions.explanation: Symbolic function substage (2–4): Characterized by mental representation—pretend play (banana as telephone) and drawing to represent absent objects. Intuitive thought substage (4–7): Characterized by primitive reasoning, 'why' questions, and conservation failure (tall glass error due to centration). Cooperative play (4–5+): Involves organized activity around a common goal with assigned roles and negotiated rules, as seen in role-playing family dinner or hospital scenarios.

questions.stem: Categorize each child outcome as MOST associated with the parenting style described by Baumrind.

items.text: High self-esteem, strong social competence, and good academic achievement
Obedient behavior but increased anxiety and lower self-esteem
Poor self-regulation, impulsivity, and entitled behavior
Strong self-regulation and capacity for autonomous decision-making
Potential aggression combined with social withdrawal in some contexts
Academic difficulties due to lack of structure and behavioral expectations

questions.explanation: Authoritative parenting (high demand + high warmth) is associated with the best outcomes: high self-esteem, social competence, academic success, and self-regulation. Authoritarian parenting (high demand + low warmth) produces outward obedience but at the cost of anxiety, lower self-esteem, and potential aggression. Permissive parenting (low demand + high warmth) results in poor self-regulation, impulsivity, entitlement, and academic difficulties due to the absence of structure and expectations.
